newsitem.title: FRANCE: France denies it broke arms embargo to Hutus.
newsitem.headline: France denies it broke arms embargo to Hutus.

text.p: France denied on Tuesday reports that it supplied arms to the former Rwandan government after their genocide of one million mostly minority Tutsis in 1994.
"I clearly and absolutely deny it. Arms sales and arms contracts have ceased completely since April 8, 1994," Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a news briefing.
The United Nations decided an arms embargo on Rwanda in May 1994 after soldiers of the former Rwandan army and Hutu militia began slaughtering Tutsis.
Documents found by British reporters near the abandoned Hutu refugee camp in Goma, eastern Zaire, appeared to show that certain French companies had continued shipping arms to the Hutus.
"The document found in the refugee camp is a document offering a service. It was never agreed. The delivery was never carried out," Rummelhardt said.

According to a still unpublished U.N. report on arms shipments to Zaire, a copy of which was obtained earlier this month by Reuters, Rwandan Hutu rebels have been amply supplied with arms from Europe and South Africa.
The report, prepared for the U.N. Security Council by a four-man, U.N.-appointed Commission of Inquiry, is part of a series documenting violations of the arms embargo.

After the killings, a million Hutus fled to eastern Zaire, including soldiers and militia. The crisis escalated recently when ethnic Tutsis in Zaire fought the Zairean army, with the refugees caught in the crossfire.
